clean_story:
Life’s edge. Extreme survival.


The "biosphere" is Earth’s thin layer where life thrives—from deep ocean vents to mountain peaks.


We often picture life as lush forests or teeming oceans.
But the real limits are stranger.
Tardigrades survive space vacuums.
Deep-mine bacteria eat rocks 3 km underground.
At -40°C, Antarctic nematodes freeze solid—then wake up.
The record? Geogemma barossii—a microbe growing at 121°C in hydrothermal vents.
That’s hotter than boiling water.
Yet even these extremes have boundaries.
No life survives above 150°C or in pure acid.
Radiation, pressure, salinity—each has a threshold.
The biosphere isn’t endless.
It’s a fragile, shifting envelope.
Panspermia.
Polyextremophiles.
The Fermi Paradox.
